awd_titl_txt: PFT-TT: Detecting Neutrinos as Instrumentation of Nuclear Reactors
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Partnerships for Innovation - Technology Translation (PFI-TT) project is to enable the widespread adoption of advanced nuclear reactors by providing a non-invasive and environmentally responsible method to account for the plutonium produced during the operation of the reactor.  Nuclear reactors serve as a source of electric power but also produce plutonium, which can be extracted from the used nuclear fuel and used for other purposes.  The proposed project will develop a next-generation plutonium detector. 

The proposed project will determine the detector performance requirements for real-world plutonium detection. Neutrino detection can track plutonium production by measuring the effect it has on the spectrum of neutrinos emitted by the reactor. This project will develop: 1) new readout electronics; and 2) a new cosmic-ray neutron shield to reduce the rate of observed background events by an order of magnitude.  This project includes a field test for system validation and verification.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The purpose of this project was to conduct R&D on the CHANDLER reactor neutrino detector technology, to study its potential uses for commercial applications, particularly for use as instrumentation in advanced nuclear reactors.  Through this grant we rebuilt our MiniCHANDLER prototype for the purposes of testing upgrades that were projected to improve the energy resolution and pattern recognition capabilities of the detector.   We studied how the technology would perform in commercial applications. 

Intellectual Merits:

CHANDLER is a novel technology for the detection of neutrinos from nuclear reactors. Nuclear reactors are a prolific source of neutrinos, which carry information on the operational state and history of the reactor. They are very weakly interacting and can easily penetrate the shielding around the reactor. This property also makes them hard to detect. Most neutrino detectors are unwieldy devices, which are typically very large and must be located deep underground to reduce the noise from cosmic-ray radiation, so that the rare neutrino interactions can be cleanly observed.  Detectors based on the CHANDLER technology are optimized to work on the surface, to be rapidly deployable and to operate with minimal oversight, without interfering with onsite operations or creating safety concerns.  The detector is based on a patented (US Patent No. 10,429,526) combination of commercially available components and has successfully demonstrated neutrino detection at the North Anna Nuclear Generating Station.  It was also the subject of a commercialization and customer discovery study through the NSF's I-Corps Program.  In this project we successfully completed a major upgrade of the light collection system.  Additionally, we made significant progress on the design and of new readout electronics which are now ready for production.  These electronics are now the focus of a commercialization effort that, while the commercial exploitation of the CHANDLER technology remains a long-term goal.  

Broader Impacts:

As a carbon-free energy source, nuclear enabling technologies like CHANDLER may one day contribute to the reduction of carbon emissions and combating global warming.   If CHANDLER technology succeeds in displacing chemical assay in advanced reactor instrumentation, it will eliminate a possible pathway for nuclear materials diversion that could lead to the proliferation of nuclear weapons.  This project has created educational opportunities for at least a dozen students from diverse backgrounds, including first-generation college students from an under-served region of Appalachia, and from historically black and Latino universities.   CHANDLER provides a broad educational experience in nuclear physics, which has helped to prepare students for careers in many fields including education, engineering, and the U.S. Navy.
